abstract: The company surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players.
snippet: The company surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 — Apple Inc. surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players.

headline.main: Apple Zooms Past Rivals, With 88% Profit Growth
headline.print_headline: Apple Zooms Past Rivals, With 88% Profit Growth

abstract: A former Apple board member kept suspicions about Apple’s options-backdating policies swirling around Steven P. Jobs.
snippet: A former Apple board member kept suspicions about Apple’s options-backdating policies swirling around Steven P. Jobs.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 — When Fred D. Anderson abruptly left Apple’s board last October as questions about the company’s stock options practices grew, a former federal regulator said it looked as if the board “threw Fred under the bus.”

headline.main: In Comments About Apple Chief, Questions of Motive
headline.print_headline: In Comments About Apple Chief, Questions of Motive

byline.original: By John Markoff and Matt Richtel

abstract: Apple surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit.
snippet: Apple surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 — Apple Inc. surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players.

abstract: When the former chief financial oficer of Apple, Fred D. Anderson, suggested that he had been misled by his former boss, Steven P. Jobs, over the improper back-dating of options, the shot echoed through Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: When the former chief financial oficer of Apple, Fred D. Anderson, suggested that he had been misled by his former boss, Steven P. Jobs, over the improper back-dating of options, the shot echoed through Silicon Valley.

headline.main: In Comments About Apple Chief, Questions of Motive
